important.title: Use Latest Documentation
important.para: Always use the latest online version of the documentation for the migration process.

sect1.title: Migration from &hpecloud; 5.0.x to &hpecloud; 5.SCP
sect1.para: The migration procedure is based on the following assumptions:

listitem.para: The customer is responsible for backing up all the control plane and deployer nodes to an external data store before starting the migration.

important.title: No Migration Rollback
important.para: We do not support rollback of migration after the process has been started.

listitem.para: Metering, monitoring, and logging (MML) data will not be migrated (a clean installation will be done using a new MML back-end included with &hpecloud; 5.SCP).

Upgrading will require re-imaging the operating system on the physical disks containing the root partition of your controller nodes. Existing data on these disks, which may include audit logs and &swift; objects, may be lost as a result. (Note that the primary OpenStack MySQL database will undergo a backup/restore as part of the upgrade process to ensure that its contents are preserved.)

Review your existing partitioning model to understand how your data will be affected by re-imaging. Any data that is not on a disk separate from the primary root partition will be lost during re-imaging. &swift; objects and audit logs.
All &compnode;s are running supported Linux distributions:
&sls; 12 SP3 for &slsa; &compnode;s
&rhla; 7.3 for &rhla; &compnode;s
The cloud data model does not contain services which are not included in &productname; &productnumber;, such as Ceph and VSA.

Any customizations to virtual environments used by &ostack; components will be lost during the upgrade process. These may include third party extensions, regardless of origin, that have not been included in &productname; &productnumber;.
No significant issues or alarms are actively being reported by &o_monitor; and &opscon;.

step.para: Because all Freezer content will be obsolete upon migrating to the new platform, it is recommended to stop Freezer jobs and eliminate historic backups.
step.screen: (old-deployer)> source ~/backup.osrc (old-deployer)> for id in $(freezer job-list -f value | awk '{print $1}') do freezer job-stop $id done (old-deployer)> for container in $(openstack container list -f value) for backup in $(openstack object list $container -f value) do openstack object delete $container $backup done done

step.para: Obtain the &hpecloud; 5.SCP installation ISO and use the mount command to make its contents available on the existing deployer:
step.screen: (old-deployer)> mkdir hos-5.scp (old-deployer)> sudo mount HOS5SCP_ISO_FILE hos-5.scp (old-deployer)> tar -xf hos-5.scp/hos/hlm-migration-tools.tar.gz

step.para: Run the validation playbook to ensure that the current cloud load and configuration is compatible with the migration process:
step.screen: (old-deployer)> cd hlm-migration-tools/ansible (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook \ -i ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/hosts/verb_hosts \ pre-migration-validations.yml
step.para: The validation playbook checks that:

listitem.para: The &hpecloud; version number is either 5.0.1 or 5.0.3
&productname; &productnumber;-compatible Linux distributions on &compnode;s
System clocks are synchronized across cloud nodes
HA capacity of &contrnode;s (L3/DHCP agent)
Configuration and capacity of &contrnode;s (&swift;, &o_blockstore;)
Data model compatibility with &productname; &productnumber; (no vsa, ceph, eon, or cmc-service)

warning.title: Check Validation Results
warning.para: Review the contents of /var/log/pre-migration-validations.log immediately to discover if any errors were identified while running the validation playbook. Any identified issues must be resolved before proceeding with the migration.

step.para: Identify a candidate seed &contrnode; in the primary control plane. This node must meet the following requirements:

listitem.para: Networking connectivity is equivalent to that of the existing deployer.
It is a member of the database cluster (running the MySQL service).
It is not actively hosting any singleton &ostack; services (cinder-volume or nova-consoleauth). Test for empty output with the following command:

step.para: Consider the effect of control plane downtime on existing DHCP leases:

listitem.para: Default DHCP lease time is 48 hours as defined in the ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/neutron-common/templates/neutron.conf.j2 file by the dhcp_lease_duration parameter.
DHCP leases are administered by &o_netw; and dnsmasq. This functionality will not be available during the control plane downtime.
DHCP clients typically renew their leases either after 50% of the lease time or upon reboot.

Normally, this leaves a 24-hour window for control plane downtime at any point before workload's DHCP leases run out and cannot be renewed. While this is typically enough for performing a migration, increasing the DHCP lease time to 144 hours is recommended to ensure that lease expiration will not be a concern that affects your migration, even if unexpected delays in the process are encountered.
To view the upcoming timeouts of DHCP leases, run the following command from each &contrnode;:
listitem.screen: for i in $(cat /var/run/neutron/dhcp/*/leases | awk '{print $1}'); do date -d @$i; done

listitem.para: To increase the DHCP lease time before migrating, open the ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/neutron-common/templates/neutron.conf.j2 file and edit the dhcp_lease_duration parameter. Commit the change, and run the neutron-configure.yml playbook. Then, continue to monitor the upcoming DHCP lease expirations as described above until all existing leases have been refreshed to a lengthier period.

step.para: Prepare the cloud data model for migration:

listitem.para: In the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/disks_*.yml files used by your server role that includes monitoring services, replace the existing Vertica partition definition with two Cassandra partitions:
listitem.screen: - name: cassandra_db size: (whatever size was used originally by vertica partition, less 1%) mount: /var/cassandra/data fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file consumer: name: vertica - name: cassandra_log size: 1% mount: /var/cassandra/commitlog fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file

listitem.para: Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml and identify the cluster definition that already includes an entry for mysql in its service-components.

Ensure that lifecycle-manager is included in the same cluster's service-components list. If it was necessary to add this as a new entry, it will also need to be removed from its original position in the deployer.
Add a new entry for nova-placement-api alongside whichever cluster already includes nova-api.
Update the servers.yml entry for all nodes in the control plane to specify distro-id: sles12sp3-x86_64 in each one.
Commit your changes to the Git model:

step.para: If the intended seed node also currently hosts &o_netw; L3 routing services, evacuate the routers from the node so that it can be re-imaged without interruption to tenant networks.

listitem.para: For non-DVR clouds, evacuate any existing &o_netw; L3 routers on the seed node:
SEED_HOST represents the name of the seed node, for example, ardana-cp1-c1-m2.

important.title: Host Selection
important.para: For correct behavior, you must use the --limit argument to select the target seed host. This will output a success or error message at the end of its run.

step.para: Re-image the seed controller as a &slsa;-based system:

listitem.para: Display the current network connections of the seed controller (before re-imaging) for reference and save it locally.
Reinstall the operating system on the seed node's primary disk using an ISO, cobbler (from the existing deployer), or other provisioner.
If using cobbler, begin the seed node re-imaging by running:
listitem.screen: (old-deployer)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (old-deployer)> sudo cobbler system remove --name SEED_NODE_ID (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=SEED_NODE_ID
listitem.para: Replace SEED_NODE_ID with the ID of the seed node from the servers.yml file.

Cobbler will initialize the seed node's networking to use the IP address of your original deployer as the default gateway. This will negatively impact the network's operation later on in the migration, and should be updated after the system is up and running. On the new seed node, edit the file /etc/sysconfig/network/routes and change the address in the line starting with "default" to point to your environment's actual default gateway. (You may be able to copy this from the value specified in your existing deployer.) Then, restart networking with:

Otherwise, if installing manually or using a proprietary tool for provisioning, reformat the primary partition (preserving the overall partitioning scheme based on the data model) and install the &sls; 12 SP3 operating system. Follow the instructions as described in , but when creating the user account and group, use the name stack instead of ardana.

important.title: Manual Installation
important.para: If the server's boot mode is set to Legacy BIOS boot, then it is possible to use cobbler. However, if the boot mode of the server is set to UEFI boot, the operating system must be installed manually.

You should also perform installation on the root disk and avoid removing any disks and partitions during the install. This way, if the seed node also originally contained &o_objstore; data, it will be left intact.

step.para: Transfer configuration and files from your existing cloud to the new seed node

listitem.para: Copy the entire home directory from the original deployer:
If cobbler will be used from the new seed for provisioning the remaining cloud &contrnode;s:
Ensure that the seed node is able to reach IPMI interfaces referenced in the servers.yml file:

If you are not able to ping IPMI IP addresses because network accessibility to the IPMIs requires special network configuration and you would like to use &lcm; for that process based on your existing data model:
listitem.screen: (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts \ hlm-refresh-facts.yml (old-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts -l SEED_NODE_ID \ osconfig-run.yml
listitem.para: Replace SEED_NODE_ID with the ID of the seed node as listed in the hosts/verb_hosts file.
Kill the DHCP services running on the old deployer:

step.para: Confirm the existence of package repository ISOs and mount the operating system image to make it available to the &hpecloud; installer.

important.title: ISO filenames
important.para: For correct behavior, the filenames of the images described below must match exactly their names in the user's home directory.

listitem.para: If your cloud includes &rhla; &compnode;s, ensure that ~/rhel7.iso was either transferred from the original deployer or is downloaded to the user's home directory.
Ensure that ~/sles12sp3sdk.iso was either transferred from the original deployer or is downloaded to the user's home directory.
Ensure that ~/sles12sp3.iso was either transferred from the original deployer or is downloaded to the home directory on the seed node under the sles12sp3.iso. Then, mount it:
listitem.screen: (seed)> sudo mkdir -p /media/cdrom (seed)> echo /home/stack/sles12sp3.iso /media/cdrom iso9660 loop 0 0 \ | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab (seed)> sudo mount -a
listitem.para: If you installed the seed node using cobbler from the original deployer, edit the primary package repository on the new seed node to point it to the ISO media instead of a remote network location.
listitem.screen: (seed)> sudo zypper rr SLES12-SP3-12.3-0 (seed)> sudo zypper ar file:/media/cdrom SLES12-SP3-12.3-0

step.para: Install &hpecloud; 5.SCP on the seed node by downloading and unpacking &hpecloud;Â 5.SCP installation content:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~; tar -xf hos-5.scp/hos/hos-5.1.0-*.tar (seed)> sudo mkdir -p /var/log/apache2 (seed)> cd ~/hos-5.1.0; ./hos-init.bash

step.para: Update repository references of &compnode; as appropriate to point to the seed node.

listitem.para: On each &slsa; compute node, remove outdated repositories that point to the old deployer. To do this, run zypper lr -u and remove listings referring to the original deployer's IP address using zypper rr REPO_NAME. Note that the repositories SLES-OS and SLES-SDK should never be removed, as they are system entries that will automatically be updated to point to the new seed node during installation.

On each &rhla; compute node, edit the repositories located in either /etc/yum.repos.d or /etc/yum/repos.d to redirect any IP addresses from the old deployer to point to the new seed node. (These references are likely to be found in the files cobbler-config.repo or rhel73.repo.)
Then, refresh the yum cache by running:

step.para: Prepare for running the migration playbook:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

step.para: Initialize ansible host facts and ensure that the existing cloud is fully addressable by the new deployer:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-refresh-facts.yml

note.title: &ostack; Clouds Only
note.para: The following step is only necessary on &ostack; clouds and should not be used in standalone &swift; deployments.

step.para: Flush the &o_ident; token cache by running the following command on a node hosting the Keystone API service. (This may be the seed node in an entry-scale environment, or a dedicated controller node in a mid-scale environment.)
step.screen: (controller)> sudo /opt/stack/service/keystone/venv/bin/keystone-manage token_flush
step.para: Then, prune the primary database to remove data that is no longer relevant:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-prune.yml

warning.title: Downtime
warning.para: The cloud will not be available until all of the following steps are completed.

step.para: Stop or pause &ostack; services on the control plane (excluding the seed that has been freshly imaged):
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ./hlm-quiesce.sh --limit '!SEED_HOST'
step.para: The SEED_HOST name must exactly match the host name that is referenced in hosts/verb_hosts, such as ardana-cp1-c1-m1.
Create a database backup by retrieving MySQL database contents from another node (not the seed) in the database cluster:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-vertica-removal-cleanup.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-export.yml \ -e dbcontent=~/mysql_dump.sql

step.para: Re-image the remaining servers in the control plane.

listitem.para: Reinstall the operating systems on the control plane primary disks using an ISO, cobbler, or other provisioner. If using cobbler:
listitem.screen: (seed)> cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost prepare-sles-grub2.yml \ -e nodelist=NODE_IDs (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml \ -e nodelist=NODE_IDs
listitem.para: In a mid-scale cloud topology, the original database content may have been stored on the non-primary drive in the system. If this was the case, the wipe_disk.yml playbook should be used after the database nodes have been re-imaged to purge the old data. For example:
(Be sure to specify your own list of database nodes matching their identifiers from the servers.yml file.)
Do not run the wipe_disk.yml playbook on any nodes containing &o_objstore; object storage.

Otherwise, if installing manually or using a proprietary tool for provisioning, reformat the primary partition (preserving the overall partitioning scheme based on the data model) and install the &sls; 12 SP3 operating system. Follow the instructions as described in , but when creating the user account and group, use the name stack instead of ardana.

step.para: Perform the &hpecloud; 5.SCP installation using flags to enable database import from the snapshot that was captured from the cloud:
step.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml -e dbcontent=~/mysql_dump.sql

step.para: At this time, the cloud should again be operational, with the exception of monitoring components that will remain offline until the upgrade to &productname; &productnumber; is fully complete.

note.title: No Downtime
note.para: These steps do not cause service downtime and can be performed while the cloud is up and running.

step.para: Delete the database backup from the seed node:
step.screen: (seed)> rm ~/mysql_dump.sql

step.para: If desired, transfer the deployer role in the &hpecloud; 5.SCP cloud to a different node, such as one that originally served as a dedicated deployer.

listitem.para: If the deployer will be moving to an entirely different cluster (for example, Database cluster to Controller cluster or standalone Deployer cluster), additional software packages need to be installed.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml and move the lifecycle-manager from its current location into the new desired cluster's service-components list. Commit the change:
listitem.screen: (seed)> git commit -a -m "Enable lifecycle-manager for new deployer"

listitem.para: Execute these steps to prepare for running playbooks:
listitem.screen: (seed)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

listitem.para: Install the lifecycle-manager services on the new deployer and remove cloud-wide references to the seed:
listitem.screen: (seed)> cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible (seed)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml -l NEW_DEPLOYER_HOST (seed)> ansible resources -i hosts/verb_hosts -a "zypper rr SLES12-SP3-12.3-0" --become
listitem.para: NEW_DEPLOYER_HOST must match the node's identity in the file hosts/verb_hosts (for example, ardana-cp1-c0-m1)
Stop the deployer-related services and repositories running on the current seed:
listitem.screen: (seed)> sudo systemctl stop dhcpd (seed)> sudo systemctl disable dhcpd (seed)> sudo systemctl stop cobblerd (seed)> sudo systemctl disable cobblerd (seed)> sudo sed -i /sles12sp3.iso/d /etc/fstab (seed)> sudo umount /media/cdrom

listitem.para: Copy the user's home directory from the seed to the new deployer:
Connect to the new deployer and initialize it for use:
listitem.screen: (new-deployer)> cd ~ (new-deployer)> sudo mkdir -p /media/cdrom (new-deployer)> echo /var/lib/ardana/sles12sp3.iso /media/cdrom iso9660 loop 0 0 \ | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab (new-deployer)> sudo mount -a (new deployer)> tar -xf hos-5.scp/hos/hos-5.1.0-*.tar (new deployer)> cd ~/hos-5.1.0 (new deployer)> ./hos-init.bash (new deployer)> cd ~/helion/hos/ansible (new deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml (new-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml (new-deployer)> ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

listitem.para: On each &slsa; compute node, remove all repositories that point to the seed node. To do this, run zypper lr -u and remove any listings referring to the original deployer's IP address using zypper rr REPO_NAME.

On each &rhla; compute node, edit the repositories located in either /etc/yum.repos.d or /etc/yum/repos.d to redirect any IP addresses from the seed node to point to the new deployer. (These references are likely to be found in the files cobbler-config.repo or rhel73.repo.)
Then, refresh the yum cache by running:
Use the new deployer to inform all other cloud nodes of its new role.

sect1.title: Migration from &hpecloud; 5.SCP to Ardana.Newton
sect1.para: The following procedure describes the process of migrating from &hpecloud; 5.SCP to Ardana.Newton.

From this point forward, all commands should be executed on the new deployer node (which will be the same as the earlier seed node unless this role was explicitly transferred using the instructions at the end of the prior section).

step.para: Convert the helion Git repository to an openstack Git repository for use by Ardana:
step.screen: cd ~ cp -r helion openstack cd openstack git checkout site
step.para: If your environment included a SES storage backend, remove all references to it from your data model. This may be done by using git revert COMMIT-ID to revert a specific commit including the SES backend definition, or git checkout hos -- FILENAME to restore an entire file to its original version (followed by git diff --staged to inspect the difference between files and ensure that you ar satisfied with the final condition of the configuration file.) Committing these edits will be necessary for the following files in the ~/openstack git repository:

listitem.para: hos/ansible/roles/GLA-API/templates/glance-api.conf.j2 (if the SES backend was additionally configured for use with &o_img;)

step.para: Save a record of all other manual changes that have been previously committed to the hos/ansible directory, as you will need to reapply them later:
step.screen: git diff hos -- hos/ansible > /tmp/hos.diff
step.para: Forcibly undo all the changes identified:
step.screen: rm -rf hos/ansible git checkout hos -- hos/ansible
step.para: Reset the codebase to make it ready for Ardana, then transform the rest of the repository:
step.screen: git commit -a -m "Resetting codebase in prep for Ardana" git branch -m hos ardana git checkout ardana sed -i 's/hos/ardana/' .gitignore git commit -a -m "Prep for Ardana" git mv hos ardana git mv hos_extensions ardana_extensions for i in $(find -L my_cloud/config -xtype l) do ln -sfn $(readlink $i | sed 's/\/hos\//\/ardana\//') $i done git commit -a -m "Conversion to Ardana" git checkout cp-persistent sed -i 's/component: helion-ca/component: ardana-ca/' \ my_cloud/persistent_state/private_data_control-plane-1.yml sed -i 's/helion_internal_ca/ardana_internal_ca/' \ my_cloud/persistent_state/private_data_control-plane-1.yml git commit -a -m "Conversion to Ardana" git checkout site git merge ardana -m "Conversion to Ardana"
step.para: Reinstate the changes that were originally made to the contents of the hos/ansible directory
step.screen: sed 's/ \([ab]\?[\/]\?\)hos\/ansible/ \1ardana\/ansible/g' /tmp/hos.diff | git apply
step.para: If merge conflicts are reported, some files may need to be edited manually to reconcile the difference between the HOS and Ardana playbooks with respect to manual changes previously made to the repository. Once this is completed, continue to commit all updates:
step.screen: git add -A git commit -a -m "Reinstated hos playbook customizations (batch)"

step.para: Remove and archive the &hpecloud; 5.SCP-related content:
step.screen: mv ~/scratch ~/scratch.scp sudo rm /etc/apache2/sites-enabled/deployer_venv_server.conf

step.para: Prepare the ardana_packager working directory to include existing &suse; repositories:
step.screen: sudo mkdir -p /opt/ardana_packager/ardana/sles12/zypper sudo ln -s /opt/hlm_packager/hlm /opt/ardana_packager/hlm sudo ln -s /opt/hlm_packager/hlm/sles12/zypper/OS \ /opt/ardana_packager/ardana/sles12/zypper/OS

step.para: Install Ardana.Newton content onto the deployer by mounting the installation media and running the following commands:
step.screen: cd ~ sudo mkdir -p /media/ardana-0.35.0 sudo mount ~/ardana-0.35.0*.iso /media/ardana-0.35.0 tar -xf /media/ardana-0.35.0/ardana/ardana-0.35.0*.tar cd ardana-0.35.0 ./ardana-init.bash

step.para: Install Ardana.Newton:
step.screen:
cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
cd ~/scratch.scp/ansible/next/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-iptables-rename.yml ansible -i hosts/verb_hosts resources --become \ -a "sed -i 's/helion/ardana/' /etc/iproute2/rt_tables"

step.para: Create the ardana user throughout all nodes in the cloud:
step.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ardana-user-create.yml

step.para: Mount the &productname; &productnumber; installation media on the host (after copying the ISO file into the user's home directory)
step.screen: sudo mkdir -p /media/cloud echo $(ls ~/HPE-HELION-*.iso) /media/cloud iso9660 loop 0 0 \ | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab sudo mount -a

step.para: Add the contents of the ISO as a Zypper repository:
step.screen: sudo zypper ar -G -f file:/media/cloud Cloud sudo zypper refresh

step.para: Begin the installation:
step.screen: sudo zypper -n in patterns-cloud-ardana ardana-ses sudo su - ardana ARDANA_INIT_AUTO=1 /usr/bin/ardana-init

step.para: This procedure creates the directory /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/PTF and adds it as a software repository. To enable a successful migration, you must add required Program Temporary Fix (PTF) RPM packages to this repository manually. These packages are provided to you by &suse; via an active L3 support contract.
Apply the PTF packages obtained in the previous step and confirm that they install correctly:
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible &prompt.ardana;ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost deployer-init.yml &prompt.sudo;zypper refresh PTF &prompt.sudo;zypper dup --from PTF &prompt.ardana;rpm -qa | grep PTF
step.para: Ensure that all migration RPMs available to you via your &suse; support contract are present in the resulting list. If any are missing, repeat the above process or contact technical support before continuing.
Apply the updates received via PTF packages to your active cloud:
step.screen: /usr/bin/ardana-init

step.para: Adjust data model to install cassandra instead of vertica (continuing as ardana user):
step.screen: cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible
step.para: Manually replace vertica with cassandra in the service-components list, and remove any entry for ops-console-monitor:
step.screen: vi ../../my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml
step.para: In files where a cassandra_db partition exists, manually update its consumer name from vertica to cassandra and add an identical consumer block to the cassandra_log partition definition:
step.screen: vi ../../my_cloud/definition/data/disks_*
step.para: If your environment includes a SES backend, add configuration files to enable it based on the instructions. (However, the site.yml and ardana-reconfigure.yml playbooks should not be used at this time.)
Save the updates to the data model:
step.screen: git commit -a -m 'Updated data model'

step.para: Build the ~/scratch directory for the upgrade:
step.screen: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

step.para: Prepare the servers for Pike infrastructure:
step.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts FND-AP2-vhosts-transition.yml

step.para: Set up package repositories for installation:
step.screen: sudo ln -s /media/cloud /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/Cloud sudo ln -s /opt/hlm_packager/hlm/sles12/zypper/extras/sles12sp3-ceph-updates \ /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/sles12sp3-ceph-updates ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ardana-replace-legacy-repos.yml

step.para: Run the &productname; &productnumber; upgrade playbook:
step.screen: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts -vvv ardana-upgrade-from-legacy.yml
step.para: Note that the ardana-upgrade-from-legacy.yml playbook is not guaranteed to be idempotent, and re-running it upon a failure may produce new errors. If this playbook fails, please contact customer support and be prepared to share details of the failure from the contents of ~/.ansible/ansible.log to determine appropriate next steps.
After the base installation has completed, the PTF and other temporary packages can be removed:
step.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible ansible -i hosts/verb_hosts resources --become -m shell \ -a "if [ -x /usr/bin/zypper ]; then zypper rr sles12sp3-ceph-updates; fi" sudo rm /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/sles12sp3-ceph-updates sudo rm /srv/www/suse-12.3/x86_64/repos/PTF/* cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost deployer-init.yml sudo zypper refresh PTF sudo zypper dup --from Cloud

step.para: Now that the upgrade has completed, it will be necessary to reboot the nodes in your cloud for changes to fully take effect and re-enable normal behavior. Reboot your cloud per the instructions in .
Determine how to handle modified policy files which restrict the admin user's privileges more tightly than in previous releases:
With this upgrade, the policy.json files have been aligned with &ostack-current;. When running &ostack; commands an operator may see messages saying Policy doesn't allow ... such as:
step.screen: Policy doesn't allow volume_extension:services:index to be performed
step.para: In this case the operator can be given permission by adding a role to the user using the openstack role add command, for example:
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;openstack role add -/-user USER_NAME -/-project PROJECT_NAME cinder_admin
step.para: Role assignments should be carefully considered. In an environment which requires separation of duties, each operator should be assigned only the roles they require to perform their duties and should use their own user account to perform their administrative tasks.
